review_title: Not a place for new software engineers
pros:
* Get to work on lots of different tech stacks
* Flexible work schedule depending on what project you're on
cons:
* No time to actually invest in learning unless you're on the bench & can learn independently
* Bench time is so exhausting - trying to get people to respond to you is weirdly difficult & it's ridiculous to think I've been hired & yet I can't get work.
* So many organizational changes make it difficult to understand where the org is headed & who to report to. Makes it easy to get lost in the churn.
* It doesn't seem like the company really cares about the individual. It's easy to get lost in the system if you're not a supporter of everything they ask you to do.
* It seems like we just sell stories rather than create anything meaningful.
* Not the place for someone trying to become a well-rounded Software Engineer or develop a specialty. They don't care what you want to do.
* Unless you're a yes-man for all the "innovation" (metaverse, NFT's, etc.) then you're not a valuable employee.

review_title: Major improvements needed, don't waste your valuable career time here.
pros: Experience on high profile projects, when enough quotas are filled, otherwise expect low impact roles.
cons: HR and benefits claim benefits but lousy on delivery. Be careful when attempting to exercise parental leave or any disability related workplace assistance. They discriminate on employees with disabilities and gender on most projects and promotions. It is very sad to watch. HR will also block promotions and project assignments if you do not fit into their quota - despite project leadership / teams / even clients asking for you as a specific named resource. A lot of ppl quit early or get indefinitely placed on the bench, until they quit, so HR won't have to technically fire you.  It is very unprofessional and unethical. Mostly about saving money or supply enough minorities so as to win bids / contracts.

-risk of stagnation is always there
-interns don't have access to many resources, including trainings

review_title: False promises, low pay, everyone wants to leave
pros: If you want to work with average people and get low pay it’s a great place to slack. Minimum hours if you want.
cons:
- Work is not valued, being friends with md is more important. Only bum kissing will get you far, good people either left or looking to leave 

- the system encourages mediocre people staying so no inspiring/intelligent colleagues in most part of the business - people either just clock in and out; or are burnt out from bum kissing. No one likes/cares about what they do

- people in strategy looks down on everyone; digital looks down on MC, MC looks down on TC, TC looks down on operation etc etc - very toxic environment

- promises for promotion/career progression but will not happen and you wouldn’t know why despite being told you’re a “top performer” and “keep doing what you are doing”. They will say there was no budget, then few months later acquired 500 people from other small competitors in smaller markets (sad) to be your boss. They don’t want to grow from within - it’s a lie

- Very low pay, 40-60% lower than industry. If you ask them they will ask you to just walk especially if you need visa sponsorship

- Loads training available but if you take them it will impact your chargeability and hence your performance. Its a joke.

- no knowledge/support function compared to MBB. Every project feels like it’s the first time ACN doing it you have to start from scratch. You will be left in the wild Wild West with no support

pros: Good salary and many bonuses.
cons:
Instead of hiring good Software Engineers, they are hiring Cheap Engineers with huge salary. As the result, you will find poor engineering practice commonly applied here.

This place is good if you need money more than anything. And also good if you haven't found which technology you belong. But if you wish to learn a Good Engineering Standard for a specific technology, then this place is definitely not for you.

The Leadership doesn't reflect company value. There is a certain leader who put too much pressure on the team, while he himself do nothing when the client abuses the internal team.

Get prepared to work more than 10 hours a day on client site. They don't care COVID-19, nor your family. You won't be given a chance to leave, until you leave the company for good. And the outboarding process is very painful.

I heard someone whose salary is not paid in the last two months of her employment. And such action never exist in the Work Agreement.

Even the recruiter hides the fact that your salary in the Work Agreement is subject to government tax (yet to be deducted).

review_title: I recommend Accenture as a way to gain experience right after you studies
pros:
Great learning plateform in which employees have access to many different subject for free. Online language lessons are also included (Any language).

The salary is ok for the average starting salary in Madrid.

Promotions/raises are given based on seniority and feedback from Project leaders. It is very structured, so as Analyst you will make a certain amount, and will get a certain raise after some time (Equal to all). Raises are not given based in performance, although you can get a bonus for High performance, at least at analyst levels. In higher levels there is a variable part of the salary depending on the projects sold.
cons:
To work in Accenture means you will probably have to do a lot of overtime, depending on the project and manager. It is a good place to start at the beginning of your career, since you are able to work with a lot of different people in project completely different.
To take into account that as an analyst, HR does not really take into account your preferences regarding the projects you want to work on. 

As a consulting company, management is very horizontal, very traditional.
